The Chinese are coming to Africa. What an appropriate title for the thread !
Facing land crunch, China exports farmers to Africa 30 Dec 2008, 0115 hrs IST, AGENCIES
Liu Jianjun is wearing a brightly coloured African tunic, the tall hat of a tribal leader, a string of red beads round his neck and carrying a stick with a secret knife in the handle. Beside him sits a portrait of Chairman Mao Zedong. It is a slightly incongruous scene but one that mirrors the ever-closer relationship between Asias economic giant China and the worlds poorest continent.
The African people yell, Mao Zedong is all right and they are very warm-hearted when Im there, said one of Chinas most prominent private sector ambassadors. The minute Chinese people get off the plane, the Africans are friendly. Chinese do not bring rifles and weapons; they bring seeds and technology.
Chinas ministry of commerce announced this month that its bilateral trade with the continent is set to hit $100 billion by the end of 2008. Africas plentiful oilfields and rich mineral deposits are top of Chinas imports, and in return the worlds most populous nation is exporting tens of thousands of its countrymen, the Independent reported.
By some estimates, 750,000 Chinese people have spent time on the continent or have moved to Africa permanently to do business and take advantage of the natural resources. And Hebei, the province from where the middle-aged Liu hails, is no exception. He reckons 10,000 farmers from Hebei alone have gone to 18 African countries in the past few years.
They work in Baoding villages, named after the dusty township where Liu lives; he likes to point out that Baoding means Protection and peace. The villages, ranging in size from 400 to 2,000 Chinese, have been set up across the continent, from Nigeria to Kenya, from Sudan to Zambia.
It is a winning formula for China, which has more than 20% of the worlds population but only 7% of its arable land. China has too many people and too little land, Liu said. In Africa, they have plenty of land and too few farmers.
